html:
The Second Developer Preview of Android 16 ü§ñ

We released the second Developer Preview of Android 16, ahead of the planned release in Q2 of 2025. Android 16 introduces major and minor API releases to allow us to drive faster innovation with more frequent API releases. We‚Äôre planning both a major and minor API release in 2025, and only the Q2 major release will include app-impacting planned behavior changes; the minor release introduces new features without these changes, so you can focus your app testing on major releases.

This developer preview focuses on performance optimization, developer tools, haptic feedback enhancements, task management, adaptive refresh rate improvements and more.

Android 16 Developer Preview 2 introduces System Triggered Profiling to help developers collect profiling data during critical scenarios like app startups or ANR events. It improves developer tools with enhanced job introspection, allowing apps to identify multiple reasons why jobs are pending and debug task scheduling more effectively. Haptic feedback enhancements include new APIs to define detailed amplitude and frequency curves for more nuanced tactile responses across devices.

Additionally, adaptive refresh rate improvements refine app behavior on devices with variable refresh rates, optimizing performance and reducing power consumption. Predictive back additions include new APIs to help play corresponding ahead-of-time animations when the back gesture is invoked.

Get started today by testing your app with Android 16 in the emulator or by flashing a system image onto a Pixel device.

Android XR üëì

We released the Developer Preview of the Android XR SDK, a toolkit to create immersive extended reality (XR) experiences on Android.

The SDK helps developers:

  • Spatialize Applications: Add 3D elements, spatial panels, and spatial audio.
  • Build Immersive Environments: Create virtual or augmented spaces.
  • Enable Natural Interactions: Support hand and eye tracking for intuitive engagement.
  • It includes Jetpack XR SDK for Compose and Material Design in XR, Unity Integration for real-time 3D development, WebXR for immersive web experiences, and OpenXR 1.1 for native C/C++ development. The Play Store will also support XR apps, with existing apps spatialized automatically.

At XR Unlocked ‚Äô24, we shared how to design intuitive and engaging apps for Android XR. We covered XR design principles, considerations, and practical approaches to interaction and UI that leverage the unique capabilities of the platform and help you elevate your app‚Äôs design.

Then, Ryan, Spencer, Tricia, and Luke discussed how to build immersive experiences with Open XR and Unity by building on top of supporting industry standards and tools familiar to XR developers. They explored OpenXR APIs, our partnership with Unity, and the experimental release of Unity for Android XR, including features and roadmap.

Additionally, if you wondered how to adapt existing Android apps for Android XR devices, Yasmine, Patrick, and Stevan covered new tools and resources available. You can start building with the Android XR SDK and see your changes come to life in the Android XR Emulator within Android Studio. Also, you can learn how to use what you already know to deliver great experiences to your users.

Spotlight Week on Android Camera and Media üì∑

The week of January 7th is a Spotlight Week on Android Camera and Media, offering resources to help you uplevel the media experiences in your app. Check out this blog post for everything that we covered during the week!

Tuesday focused on the latest releases in CameraX and Media3, including guidance on building camera apps with Compose.

Wednesday emphasized creating premium user experiences, such as utilizing the Media Performance Class and enabling HDR video capture. We featured Google Drive‚Äôs implementation of Ultra HDR images and Instagram‚Äôs enhancement of in-app image capture with Night Mode.

Thursday addressed adapting camera and media apps for large screens and the new Android XR platform, covering media experiences on large devices, implementing tabletop mode for camera applications, and preparing apps for XR with considerations for spatial audio and video.

Friday delved into media creation, exploring Media3‚Äôs Transformer module for media processing, showcasing the 1 Second Everyday app, and introducing a new API for capturing concurrent camera streams. Android GDE Tom Colvin also shared how he built a hand gesture recognizer app with CameraX and MediaPipe.

Articles üìù

Reddit improved app startup speed by over 50% using Baseline Profiles and R8

Ben Weiss collaborated with Reddit to explore how they leveraged Baseline Profiles, the R8 compiler, and Jetpack Compose to reduce startup times, enhance rendering performance, optimize bytecode, and modernize legacy UI, improving both user and developer experiences.

What‚Äôs new in CameraX 1.4.0 and a sneak peek of Jetpack Compose support üì∑

Scott Nien showcased the expanded HDR capabilities, preview stabilization, and versatile effects framework in CameraX 1.4.0. He also demonstrated how to seamlessly integrate CameraX with Jetpack Compose, empowering developers to leverage Android‚Äôs camera capabilities for creating exceptional app experiences.

How Instagram enabled users to take stunning Low Light Photos üìπ

Donovan McMurray detailed how Instagram improved its Android app with Night Mode, enabling users to capture higher-quality photos in low-light settings. This feature leverages Android‚Äôs Camera Extensions API to tap into device-specific capabilities, ensuring a consistent and scalable experience across devices.

Unlocking the Power of CameraX in Jetpack Compose

Jolanda Verhoef demonstrated how to integrate the camera-compose APIs into your app, showcasing the delightful UI experiences they enable. In Part 1, she covered building a basic camera preview using the new camera-compose artifact, including permission handling and basic integration. In Part 2, she implemented a visual tap-to-focus feature using the Compose gesture system, graphics, and coroutines.

Performance Class helps Google Maps deliver premium experiences

Nevin Mital demonstrated how Google Maps leveraged MPC to roll out a UI transparency feature exclusively to higher-performing devices and provided guidance on implementing MPC in your apps with the Core Performance library.

Get your apps ready for 16 KB page size devices

Yacine Rezgui walked you through the essential steps to prepare your apps for 16 KB page size devices, unlocking performance enhancements, enabling future innovations, and delivering smoother, more immersive app experiences to users.

Android Studio Ladybug Feature Drop üêû

Steven Jenkins announced the stable release of Android Studio‚Äôs Ladybug Feature Drop, introducing five Gemini in Android Studio features, Animation Preview support for Wear Tiles, and an App Links Assistant to simplify app development. These enhancements are designed to improve developer productivity and support the creation of high-quality Android applications.

AndroidX Releases üöÄ

There were a lot of alpha releases.

To help you build for Android XR, we have added:

  • ARCore for Jetpack 1.0.0-alpha01 for advanced perception capabilities
  • Jetpack Compose for XR 1.0.0-alpha01 for declaratively building Spatial UI layouts
  • Material Design for XR 1.0.0-alpha01 for component and layout guidance
  • Jetpack SceneCore 1.0.0-alpha01 for 3D content manipulation
  • XR Runtime 1.0.0-alpha01 has fundamental pieces of functionality for the Jetpack XR suite of library experiences

For Camera and Media, we have added:

  • Camera Media3 1.0.0-alpha01 is adapter library for using Media3 effects with CameraX
  • Media3 1.6.0-alpha01 adds a lot of changes to the ExoPlayer, Transformer, Extractors, UI and more

Transition Version 1.6.0-alpha01 sets the disjoint parent for ViewOverlays used to animate its transitions.

Tv-Material 1.1.0-alpha01 changes FocusEnterExitScope.cancelFocus() to cancelFocusChange() and replaces FocusProperties.enter and FocusProperties.exit with onEnter and onExit.

Don‚Äôt fret, there‚Äôs stability ‚Äî there were also some stable releases.

AndroidX Core 1.16.0-alpha01 has a fix for inset dispatching for Views.

ViewPager 1.1.0 is stable and adds support for Android 12 stretch over scroll edge effect and nullability annotations in ViewPager.

Activity 1.10.0 is stable and adds a new LocalActivity composition local that provides the Activity for the current scope and PhotoPicker allows picking images in order and choosing which tab should be initially visible.

RecyclerView 1.4.0 is stable and has Adaptive refresh rate support.

Now then‚Ä¶ üëã

That‚Äôs it for this week, with the Second Developer Preview of Android 16, Android XR, the Spotlight Week on Android Camera and Media, the Android Studio Ladybug Feature Drop and more!

Check back soon for your next update from the Android developer universe! üí´
